_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Fusible links on emergency shutoff valves, remotely actuated emergency shutoff valves.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Low melting temperature instrument air piping which actuates pneumatic emergency shutoff valves

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Level III Process
NGL Supply Terminal Company, LLC
Port Hudson Terminal

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The Port Hudson Terminal is committed to protecting the health and safety of company personnel, contractors working in the facility, our neighbors in the surrounding community and the environment.  This commitment is supported by senior management and is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training and in considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility.  The facility does not anticipate having any type of uncontrolled release.  However, if an uncontrolled release does occur, the personnel at the facility will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the plant, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Port Hudson Terminal Facility off loads butane and natural gasoline transport trucks into eight 90,000-gallon water capacity storage tanks and delivers these products to customers via pipeline.  These materials are considered flammable mixtures containing substances such as methane, ethane, propane, iso-butane, n-butane, iso pentane, n pentane, and hexane. The Port Hudson Terminal Facility does not use or store any regulated toxic substances above the EPA set threshold levels.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Multiple storage vessels within the process were evaluated for the worst case and alternative release scenarios.  Results of the worst-case release scenario indicate that the process is subject to RMP Program Level 3 requirements.  Details of the worst case and alternative release scenarios are included with the backup documentation associated with this RMP plan.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
This facility is regulated by 29CFR 1910.119 (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemical), 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans), as well as other federal, sta

te and local regulations which are in place to reduce the potential for the release of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This facility has implemented the PSM elements to facilitate accidental release prevention.  Process safety information, consisting of technical standards, specifications and levels, promotes safe process design and operation.  Process hazard analysis evaluates hazards against safeguards needed to mitigate likelihood of an accidental release. Process changes are managed through the management of change procedure, by considering the impact that a change will have on the rest of the process.  For new or significantly changed processes, a pre-startup safety review is conducted as a final check to enable safe start up.  

The employee participation program promotes the development of necessary expertise, experiences, judgment, and proactive initiative within the workforce.  A comprehensive training program ensures that employees are knowledgeable about the processes they are responsible to operate and control.  Operating procedures explain correct startup, operation and shutdown procedures for various equipment in the process.  The hot work program is in place to promote safety of jobs involving potential ignition sources.  The mechanical integrity program ensures that equipment is maintained inspected and tested for ongoing safety.  A contractor safety evaluation program is in place to ensure hire of contractors that will not compromise job or facility safety.   

The facility has a policy of investigating every incident, which may have possibly resulted in a release, to prevent a similar accident from recurring.  The facility has established an audit procedure to assure the continued integrity of the prevention program.

5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Port Hudson Terminal has not had any RMP-reportable accidents within the last five years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility is a non-responding facility and has coordinated with the local fire departm

ent for response to large accidental releases.  As a non-responding facility, the RMP emergency response program and emergency response plan requirements (40 CFR 68.95) are not applicable at this facility.  However, the facility does maintain an emergency response plan that serves as guidance for facility employees to notify first responders, secure critical operations before evacuation, evacuate the facility, and account for personnel, among other items.  Facility personnel are trained in procedures and use of equipment appropriate to their role in response to small accidental releases.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
NGL Supply Terminal Company, LLC will continually strive for safety improvement.  Periodic process safety inspections and Process Hazard Analysis will be conducted followed with timely response.  NGL shares lessons learned from other similar facilities as appropriate to prevent similar incidents.
